messages.message:
The BriefTropical Storm Debby is moving up the East Coast, bringing heavy rain to areas as far as the Great Lakes and New Jersey.
The center of the storm was over the Atlantic Ocean near Charleston, South Carolina, on Wednesday afternoon.
FILE-Homes sit on a flooded street due to Tropical Storm Debby on August 6, 2024 in Charleston, South Carolina.
Debby could make a second landfall in either North Carolina or South Carolina, expected late Wednesday or early Thursday.
(Credit: ExpandTropical Storm Warnings are still in effect for the South Carolina and southeastern North Carolina coasts.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. (WBTV) - Tropical Storm Debby was expected to make a second landfall in South Carolina late Wednesday or early Thursday.
Both North and South Carolina, but especially South Carolina, were forecast to receive potentially historic amounts of rain on Thursday, Aug. 8 through Friday, Aug. 9.
Tropical Storm Debby made a second landfall early Thursday morning in the Carolinas after churning over the Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday.
Flood warnings active for some countiesFlood warnings have been issued for two Charlotte-area counties in North Carolina and two in South Carolina as Tropical Storm Debby moves through the region Thursday.
According to Kim Stenson, director of the South Carolina Emergency Management Division, the anticipated rainfall could set new records for the state.

A light earthquake magnitude 4 (ml/mb) has occurred on Saturday, Bonin Islands, Japan region (0 miles).
Exact time and date of earthquake 13/07/24 / 2024-07-13 18:51:45 / July 13, 2024 @ 6:51 pm UTC/GMT.
A tsunami warning has not been issued (Does not indicate if a tsunami actually did or will exist).
Ids that are associated to the earthquake: us6000nexi.
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Distances, Parameters, Date-Time, Location and details about this quake, detected near: Bonin Islands, Japan region.

A light earthquake magnitude 4.4 (ml/mb) strikes southern East Pacific Rise (0 miles) on Wednesday.
Event ids that are associated to the earthquake: us6000nink.
Id of event: us6000nink.
A tsunami warning has not been issued (Does not indicate if a tsunami actually did or will exist).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Distances, Parameters, Date-Time, Location and details about this quake, detected near: southern East Pacific Rise.

A light earthquake magnitude 4.9 (ml/mb) has struck on Tuesday, 253 km SW of Longyearbyen, Svalbard and Jan Mayen (157 miles).
A tsunami warning has not been issued (Does not indicate if a tsunami actually did or will exist).
Exact location of earthquake, longitude 7.6355 East, latitude 76.7521 North, depth = 10 km.
The earthquake was roughly at a depth of 10 km (6 miles).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Distances, Parameters, Date-Time, Location and details about this quake, that has occurred near: 253 km SW of Longyearbyen, Svalbard and Jan Mayen.

TOKYO -- A powerful earthquake struck off Japan's southern coast on Thursday, triggering a tsunami advisory.
Residents were urged to stay away from the coastline, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or serious damage.
The agency said tsunami waves of up 50 centimeters (1.6 feet) were detected along parts of Kyushu's southern coast and the nearby island of Shikoku about a half hour after the quake struck.
Earthquakes in areas with nuclear power plants have been a major concern since a massive earthquake and tsunami in March 2011 triggered the Fukushima nuclear disaster.
An earthquake on Jan. 1 in Japan's north-central region of Noto left more than 240 people dead.

A﻿ powerful earthquake struck off Japan 's southern coast on Thursday, triggering a tsunami advisory.
The Japan Meteorological Agency said the quake registered a preliminary magnitude of 6.9 and was centered off the eastern coast of Japan's southern main island of Kyushu at a depth of about 30 kilometres.
It issued a tsunami advisory, predicting waves of up to one metre (or 3.3 feet) along the southern coast of Kyushu and nearby island of Shikoku.
The Japan Meteorological Agency said the quake registered a preliminary magnitude of 6.9 and was centered off the eastern coast of Japan's southern main island of Kyushu at a depth of about 30 kilometres.
An earthquake on January 1 in Japan's north-central region of Noto left more than 240 people dead.

A powerful earthquake struck off Japan's southern coast on Thursday, triggering a tsunami advisory.
The Japan Meteorological Agency said the quake registered magnitude 7.1 and was centered off the eastern coast of Japan's southern main island of Kyushu at a depth of about 30 kilometers (18.6 miles).
It issued a tsunami advisory, predicting waves of up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) along the southern coast of Kyushu and nearby island of Shikoku.
Operators of nuclear plants on Kyushu and Shikoku said they were checking to see if there was any damage to them.
An earthquake on Jan. 1 in Japan's north-central region of Noto left more than 240 people dead.

It issued a tsunami advisory, predicting waves of up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) along the southern coast of Kyushu and nearby island of Shikoku.

Japan earthquake: Magnitude 7.1 quake hits southern part of island nation, tsunami warning issuedThe quake was centred off the eastern coast of Japan's southern main island of Kyushu at a depth of about 30 kilometreA powerful earthquake struck off Japan's southern coast on Thursday, triggering a tsunami advisory.
The Japan Meteorological Agency said the quake registered magnitude 7.1 and was centred in waters off the eastern coast of Japan's southern main island of Kyushu at a depth of about 30 kilometres (18.6 miles).
The quake most strongly shook Nichinan city and nearby areas in Miyazaki prefecture on Kyushu island.
The agency said tsunami waves of up 50 centimetres (1.6 feet) were detected along parts of Kyushu's southern coast and the nearby island of Shikoku about a half hour after the quake struck.
Earthquakes in areas with nuclear power plants have been a major concern since a massive earthquake and tsunami in March 2011 triggered the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

LONDON -- A strong earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.1 has rocked the coast of southern Japan as tsunami advisories have been triggered in the region, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
The epicenter of the earthquake is just a dozen miles off the coast of the city of Miyazaki on the island of Kyushu in Japan.
The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a tsunami advisory, predicting waves of up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) along the southern coast of Kyushu and nearby island of Shikoku.
People have been urged to stay away from the coast or river and have been warned that other quakes -- even on the same magnitude --may occur.
It would’ve been strong enough to knock over furniture, damage some concrete buildings and even topple some wooden ones.

7.1 magnitude earthquake strikes coast of Japan, tsunami advisories triggeredLONDON -- A strong earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.1 has rocked the coast of southern Japan as tsunami advisories have been triggered in the region, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
The epicenter of the earthquake is just a dozen miles off the coast of the city of Miyazaki on the island of Kyushu in Japan.
Miyazaki, with a population of approximately 400,000 people, is now on alert for potential tsunamis in the aftermath of the quake.
The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a tsunami advisory, predicting waves of up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) along the southern coast of Kyushu and nearby island of Shikoku.
People have been urged to stay away from the coast or river and have been warned that other quakes -- even on the same magnitude --may occur.

Japan Earthquake: A powerful earthquake struck off Japan's southern coast on Thursday, triggering a tsunami advisory.
The Japan Meteorological Agency said the quake registered magnitude 7.1 and was centred off the eastern coast of Japan's southern main island of Kyushu at a depth of about 30 km (18.6 miles).
It issued a tsunami advisory, predicting waves of up to 1 metre (3.3 feet) along the southern coast of Kyushu and nearby island of Shikoku.
Japan sits on the Pacific 'Ring of Fire', the line of seismic faults encircling the Pacific Ocean, and is one of the world's most earthquake-prone countries.
An earthquake on Jan 1 in Japan's north-central region of Noto left more than 240 people dead.

The National Hurricane Center says Debby came ashore early Thursday near Bulls Bay, South Carolina.
It is now a tropical storm with maximum sustained winds at 50 mph (80 kph).
Moisture from the tropical storm strengthened another system Tuesday evening, which caused strong thunderstorms, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Kleebauer.

A 6.9-magnitude earthquake followed by a 7.1 tremor struck off southern Japan on Thursday, the United States Geological Survey said, with the local meteorological agency warning of tsunamis striking coastal areas.
The USGS said that the first quake hit at 4.42pm (0742 GMT) at a depth of 33 kilometres (20 miles), about 29km southeast of Miyazaki on Kyushu.
The second struck less than a minute later at a depth of 26m and was 20km northeast of Miyazaki.
Visitors to the Peace Park crouch as an earthquake alert was issued in Nagasaki, western Japan.
In March 2022, a 7.4-magnitude quake off the coast of Fukushima shook large areas of eastern Japan, killing three people.

The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) also said there was one quake with a magnitude of 7.1.

A washed out road and bridge in Lyndon, Vt. is shown Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024, more than a week after storms caused flooding.
(AP Photo/ Lisa Rathke)LYNDON, Vt. (AP) — The Vermont town of Lyndon was hit by severe flash floods twice last month.
It came three weeks after after flooding in the north and center of the state from the remnants of Hurricane Beryl.
That storm killed two people, including a driver in the village who was swept away by floodwaters.
The reaction is more significant considering the state the town is in, he said.

LYNDON, Vt. (AP) — The Vermont town of Lyndon was hit by severe flash floods twice last month.
It came three weeks after after flooding in the north and center of the state from the remnants of Hurricane Beryl.

A powerful earthquake struck off Japan's southern coast on Thursday, triggering a tsunami advisory that urged residents to stay away from the coastline.
The Japan Meteorological Agency said the quake registered magnitude 7.1 and was centered in waters off the eastern coast of Japan's southern main island of Kyushu at a depth of about 30 kilometers (18.6 miles).
The quake most strongly shook Nichinan city and nearby areas in Miyazaki prefecture on Kyushu island.
They later issued an assessment that the potential for a future quake in the area from Kyushu to central Japan is higher than previously predicted.
He urged residents of the affected region to stay away from the coastline.

However, the quake prompted seismologists to hold an emergency meeting in which they reassessed and raised the level of risk of major quakes associated with the Nankai Trough east of southern Japan.
The Japan Meteorological Agency said that Thursday's quake registered magnitude 7.1 and was centered in waters off the eastern coast of Kyushu at a depth of about 19 miles below sea surface.
The quake most strongly shook Nichinan city and nearby areas in Miyazaki prefecture on Kyushu island.
Seismologists at the agency held an emergency meeting to analyze whether the quake had affected the nearby Nankai Trough, the source of past devastating earthquakes.
The agency said it will continue to closely watch movements of plates near the Nankai Trough.
